docs.lead_paragraph: Its staid name has the ring of venerability, but the Freiburg Baroque Orchestra is only a dozen years old, making it a relative newcomer in the world of period instrument bands. The group, which is directed by its concertmaster, Gottfried von der Goltz, played an all-Mozart concert on Thursday evening as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall. The Freiburg ensemble has much to recommend it. Its roster is compact but not minimal: some period-instrument groups use fewer than this one's six first and five second violins, four violas, four cellos and two basses, let alone its three horns and doublings of all the winds except flute. And where some early music string players produce a sound that veers toward the smoothness and depth of modern strings, these musicians revel in the gamey, textured tone that early strings can produce.

headline.main: Playing Both Sides, Zesty and Serene

docs.lead_paragraph: People at a shoe market here could not keep quiet about why they still hate the rebels. They stood in a polite, if loud, line to complain. They were not afraid to give their names, even after the police in this rebel-held city arrived at the market. When asked what good the rebels had done since the war began a year ago, dozens yelled out in Swahili with one voice, ''Nothing!''

headline.main: Rebels Can't Conquer the Hearts of the Congolese

docs.abstract: Rebels seeking to overthrow Pres Laurent Kabila of Congo have been unpopular with populace, even as they conquered nearly half of country; rebels are linked too closely with Rwanda, which provides them with troops and arms but is despised by many ordinary Congolese; Pres Kabila is unpopular, but his stature in capital of Kinshasa, in west of country, soars when compared with rebels who rule east; Congolese anger is aimed at fact that two rebellions in Congo, in 1996 and 1998, began in part after Rwandan soldiers crossed into Congo to chase Hutu miltants; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Eight months pregnant, Deborah Edwards smoothed a thin hospital gown over her bulging belly, nibbled at a graham cracker and ticked off the reasons she had spent a week confined to the maternity ward of George Washington University Hospital here, a month before her baby is due. At 42 she is, in medical parlance, of ''advanced maternal age.'' She had no prenatal care until last month: after 20 years of marriage and two adopted children, she said she had no idea she was pregnant. She weighs 208 pounds, up from 196. She has diabetes, which puts her baby in danger. And her high blood pressure has worsened into preeclampsia, a condition that could kill her if it is not carefully monitored. ''I'm concerned,'' she said, ''but I'm not worried. I know I'm being cared for.''

headline.main: Black Mothers' Mortality Rate Under Scrutiny

docs.abstract: Black Mothers' Mortality Rate Under Scrutiny** Medical experts are struggling to understand why black women in US are nearly four times as likely to die in childbirth, or shortly thereafter, as white women; disparity, which has remained about same for last four decades, holds true even for women who are middle class and have health insurance; has renewed interest among scientists and legislators in problem that many people think no longer exists; Reps Nita M Lowey and Jo Ann Emerson have convened panel of doctors, women's health advocates and disease control centers officials to discuss maternal mortality and garner support for bill that would provide additional Federal money to study it; graph; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Eight months pregnant, Deborah Edwards smoothed a thin hospital gown over her bulging belly, nibbled at a graham cracker and ticked off the reasons she had spent a week confined to the maternity ward of George Washington University Hospital here, a...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''In this country, we have a certain standard of expectation about the risk of women dying in pregnancy, and black women are off the scale right now.'' DR. DAVID SATCHER, the United States Surgeon General. [29]
